data.title: Feature Request: Multi Root Workspace Theme/Colors - use colors to visibly distinguish tabs
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.16.0-insider
- OS Version: Windows 10 x64

Steps to Reproduce:

1. Create multi root workspace
2. observe the tab color, folder color etc.

Feature Request: 
I love the multi root feature. It would be nice to have visual indication of root folder for currently visible open file. 

options:
* Different color for tabs from same root. tabs may mix on tab bar
* tab groping for same root folder on tab bar - with color indication, like in internet explorer
* it would also be helpful to change the root in the "Open Editors" section, when you switch files from different group it changes text with  active root like "OPEN EDITORS - root folder 1" or "OPEN EDITORS - full path of root". reversing path (folder/paretnfolder/c: instead of c:\parentfolder\folder") may be helpful to correctly identify the actual root in case we have same name of folder from different folder hierarchy.

data.title: Error in  Italian i8n
data.body:
<!-- Do you have a question? Please ask it on http://stackoverflow.com/questions/tagged/vscode. -->

<!-- Use Help > Report Issues to prefill these. -->
- VSCode Version: 1.15.1
- OS Version: Windows 10 x64

Steps to Reproduce:

1. Set language to Italian
2. Open search bar (Ctrl + F)
2. Type something that should have no results 
3. Notice the wrong translation: "Nessuna impostazione corrispondente"

**This actually makes the search input box too short to be useful**

Expected
- Translation should be the same as in other places: "Nessun risultato"

Reproduces without extensions: Yes

Affected files:
`i18n/ita/src/vs/editor/contrib/find/browser/findWidget.i18n.json`
(key: `label.noResults`)

data.title: [x64] Unable to install extensions from command line
data.body:
- VSCode Version: Code 1.15.1 (41abd21afdf7424c89319ee7cb0445cc6f376959, 2017-08-16T18:07:25.676Z)
- OS Version: Windows_NT x64 10.0.14393
- Extensions: Not yet installed...

---

Steps to Reproduce:

1. Install the new one, 64 bit version of Visual Studio Code.
2. Try install any extension via CLI:
      * `$ code --install-extension ms-vscode.csharp`
3. Wait for the _Heat death of the universe_ with messages in console:
```
Found 'ms-vscode.csharp' in the marketplace.
Installing...
(node:6584) UnhandledPromiseRejectionWarning: Unhandled promise rejection (rejection id: 1): TypeError: this._state.then is not a function
(node:6584) DeprecationWarning: Unhandled promise rejections are deprecated. In the future, promise rejections that are not handled will terminate the Node.js process with a non-zero exit code.
```

4. It is possible that it will finish eventually, but I was waiting about 30 minutes (for the first time), and then I had pressed `Ctrl + C`. When I was checking all extensions which I would like to use, I was waiting less then one minute for each one, but in both cases Process Explorer shows 0% of CPU usage for VS Code.

---

Why I would like to install extensions from console? Well I have got PowerShell script which will install all of from my list, and then synchronizes configuration with OneDrive and Git repo via Hard Links (see: [GitHub](https://github.com/DominikJaniec/EnvConfigs/blob/6069a7aa53c5e950734a9645285c0927d397563a/vscode/_prepare.ps1#L37)). This script was working for previous version of VS Code which was 32 bit. Finally extensions were installed via _Extension Manager's tab_. Here is a list of extensions which I had checked:
  * donjayamanne.githistory
  * hoovercj.haskell-linter
  * Ionide.Ionide-fsharp
  * ms-vscode.csharp
  * ms-vscode.PowerShell
  * ms-vscode.vs-keybindings
  * sbrink.elm
  * streetsidesoftware.code-spell-checker
  * Vans.haskero
  * vscodevim.vim
  * yzane.markdown-pdf

data.title: MacOS ctrl-h doesn't work correctly with IME
data.body:
- VSCode Version: Code 1.15.1 (41abd21afdf7424c89319ee7cb0445cc6f376959, 2017-08-16T17:15:57.756Z)
- OS Version: Darwin x64 16.3.0 (macOS)
- Extensions: --disable-extensions

---

Steps to Reproduce:

1. Open any file.
2. Turn on an IME such as macOS standard IME or Google Japanese IME.
3. Write some texts with the IME.
4. Put `ctrl + h`.

Expected: Delete the last character on the IME just like backspace.
[![https://gyazo.com/4e87f8a0ace2e8dfde4ee4a0d0b11622](https://i.gyazo.com/4e87f8a0ace2e8dfde4ee4a0d0b11622.gif)](https://gyazo.com/4e87f8a0ace2e8dfde4ee4a0d0b11622)
(in CotEditor)

Actual: Delete the last character on the IME __and the character before the IME input.__
[![https://gyazo.com/64eb3ac6fda1cf14f95935bc41f6187d](https://i.gyazo.com/64eb3ac6fda1cf14f95935bc41f6187d.gif)](https://gyazo.com/64eb3ac6fda1cf14f95935bc41f6187d)


In the same way, ctrl-A, ctrl-F, and ctrl-B don't work correctly.
I think this is because key down event propagation is not stopped even if the IME is enabled.
https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode/issues/25023 and https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode/pull/24980 are related to this issue.

<!-- Launch with `code --disable-extensions` to check. -->
Reproduces without extensions: Yes

data.title: 'Git: Open Changes' doesn't focus the newly opened tab with the diffs
data.body:
- VSCode Version: Code - Insiders 1.16.0-insider (aebaece67321b35f133be393fe8adcd50333d5ee, 2017-08-18T05:22:55.860Z)
- OS Version: Windows_NT x64 10.0.15063
- Extensions: 

Extension|Author (truncated)|Version
---|---|---
Bookmarks|ale|0.15.2
project-manager|ale|0.19.0
vscode-eslint|dba|1.2.11
gitlens|eam|4.4.0
EditorConfig|Edi|0.9.4
prettier-vscode|esb|0.22.1
auto-close-tag|for|0.4.3
beautify|Hoo|1.1.1
atom-keybindings|ms-|3.0.1
vetur|oct|0.9.4
stylelint|shi|0.28.0
---

Steps to Reproduce:

1. Open the command pallet.
2. Invoke "Git: Open Changes"  (there must be some outstanding changes in the current git repo)
3. The new tab with the changes opens.
4. The tab is *NOT* focused, so I had to grab the mouse and perform the click. Without focus, the keyboard navigation in the diff view is not working (like the up/down arrow, for example).
5. I have some extra keybindings, specially for this diff view, and they don't work as well, until I focus the diff view.

This seems to be a regression, it worked fine earlier.

<!-- Launch with `code --disable-extensions` to check. -->
Reproduces without extensions: Yes

data.title: Fix grammar for update alert
data.body: For the update alert, `Windows 64 bits` should be `64-bit Windows`.

data.title: [theming] Access theme's colors programmatically

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

data.body:
I think we should add support for accessing theme's colors programmatically. 

For instance let's take as an example the popular [OneDark Pro](https://github.com/Binaryify/OneDark-Pro/blob/master/themes/OneDark-Pro.json) theme, I'd like to access colors defined under [tokenColors](https://github.com/Binaryify/OneDark-Pro/blob/master/themes/OneDark-Pro.json#L67).

My use case: I'm making an extension that decorates some tokens, and I'd like them to have the same color that comments have in my theme, the problem is that the regex I use to find those tokens depends on some configurable value, so I cannot pre-compute it in advance and just put it in a `.tmLanguage` file.

It's already possible to somehow access colors defined under the [colors](https://github.com/Binaryify/OneDark-Pro/blob/master/themes/OneDark-Pro.json#L4) key, via something like `new vscode.ThemeColor ( 'activityBar.background' )`, adding support for this sounds like a useful generalization to me.

What do you think?

data.title: Light bulb only showing for markers and words
data.body:
- VSCode Version: code-oss-dev 1.16.0 (Commit unknown, Date unknown)
- OS Version: Darwin x64 16.7.0

---

**Steps to Reproduce:**

1. In a build of VSCode with TS 2.5
2. Write a `ts` file:

```ts
class FOO {
    bar() {
        return 123;
    }
}
```

3. In the file, highlight `123`


**Expected**
There are code actions to extract `123` to its own method. The lightbulb should be shown for these

**Actual**
The code action lightbulb only shows up when there is no selection, such as placing the cursor before the `123` like so: `|123`. If the `123` is selected, lightbulb goes away but you can still manually trigger the code action context menu

<!-- Launch with `code --disable-extensions` to check. -->
Reproduces without extensions: Yes/No

data.title: Improve React support (overview)
data.body:
This is an aggregate issue tracking the issue/bugs we need to have a more complete React experience within VS Code.

**Editor**
- https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode/issues/5961 : Enable CSS autocompletion within string literals to enable css-in-js abstractions like styled-component, glamours, etc.

**Snippets**

**Debugging**

data.title: [Markdown] Language specifier after triple backtick should not be case sensitive
data.body:
Paste this into a Markdown file:

\`\`\`CSharp
using System;
\`\`\`

The C# code inside will not be highlighted in the editor. However, it gets highlighted in the previewer, and when you upload the markdown file to GitHub and view it there.

Lowercasing `CSharp` gets it highlighted in the editor:

\`\`\`csharp
using System;
\`\`\`

data.title: Bug: Exclude active file from compare list (Cannot compare with self) Fixes: #31853
data.body:
The "Compare Active File With..." does not allow to compare the active file to self
yet the active file is included in the quick picklist.

PR excludes globalResourceToCompare from compare picklist.

Fixes: #31853

data.title: C++ assertion failure after resuming Windows
data.body:
Version 1.14.0-insider
Commit c854b698d2af794a0a3c6645133b48b776e58a28
Date 2017-06-27T09:40:11.680Z
Shell 1.6.6
Renderer 56.0.2924.87
Node 7.4.0

Windows 10, 15063.540

I realize now that my version is pretty old, so maybe this is already fixed, but I'm reporting it anyway because I didn't find a matching issue (it's not #31782 because the assertion is different).


I got this error waiting for me today after resuming Windows from hibernation. I was unable to reproduce it, though.

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/6010463/29476607-14994062-8465-11e7-960f-b8f02cb8a436.png)


It was coming from the process with the command line `"C:\Program Files (x86)\Microsoft VS Code Insiders\Code - Insiders.exe" "c:\Program Files (x86)\Microsoft VS Code Insiders\resources\app\out\bootstrap" --type=terminal`.

I tried to debug it but somehow my JIT debugger didn't launch when pressing retry... I did manage to get a stack trace from Process Hacker before, though - but it's not too informative due to missing symbols, I think:

```0, ntoskrnl.exe!KiDeliverApc+0x13d
1, ntoskrnl.exe!KiSwapThread+0x337
2, ntoskrnl.exe!KiCommitThreadWait+0x101
3, ntoskrnl.exe!KeWaitForSingleObject+0x2b8
4, win32kfull.sys!xxxRealSleepThread+0x2d8
5, win32kfull.sys!xxxSleepThread2+0x97
6, win32kfull.sys!NtUserWaitMessage+0x42
7, ntoskrnl.exe!KiSystemServiceCopyEnd+0x13
8, wow64cpu.dll!CpupSyscallStub+0xc
9, wow64cpu.dll!Thunk0Arg+0x5
10, wow64.dll!Wow64KiUserCallbackDispatcher+0x3930
11, wow64.dll!Wow64LdrpInitialize+0x120
12, ntdll.dll!LdrpInitializeProcess+0xfc1
13, ntdll.dll!_LdrpInitialize+0x506cc
14, ntdll.dll!LdrpInitialize+0x3b
15, ntdll.dll!LdrInitializeThunk+0xe
16, win32u.dll!NtUserWaitMessage+0xc
17, user32.dll!DialogBox2+0x102
18, user32.dll!InternalDialogBox+0xd1
19, user32.dll!SoftModalMessageBox+0xb99
20, user32.dll!MessageBoxWorker+0x29a
21, user32.dll!MessageBoxTimeoutW+0x165
22, user32.dll!MessageBoxW+0x1a
23, pty.node+0xea9b (No unwind info)
24, pty.node+0x8f59 (No unwind info)
25, pty.node+0x35e8 (No unwind info)
26, pty.node+0x1d7c (No unwind info)
27, node.dll!v8::internal::Builtins::UnsupportedThrower+0x1832 (No unwind info)
28, node.dll!v8::internal::Builtins::UnsupportedThrower+0x1bab (No unwind info)
29, 0x1938623e (No unwind info)
30, 0x342720ce (No unwind info)
31, 0x34271fef (No unwind info)
```

Not sure if this is caused by VSCode or by node-pty itself, though, so if you think the issue is in node-pty itself, we can move this issue to there.

data.title: Fix quick navigate arrow keys
data.body: Fix https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode/issues/32793
